_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Section 1 ? Facility Information

The GB Biosciences facility produces agricultural chemicals.  The plant has three covered processes ? Isophthalonitrile (IPN), Chlorothalonil (CTL), and chlorine distribution.

The CTL unit produces a fungicide, trade name Daconil? and Bravo? which is a fungicide for bananas, potatoes, peanuts, turf and other crop areas.  Chlorine is received in 180,000 pound rail cars, and is unloaded and distributed as a raw material in this process.  Chlorine is reacted with IPN to form chlorothalonil in a vapor phase reaction in the presence of catalyst.

The IPN for the CTL process is produced at GB Biosciences in the IPN unit.  Ammonia is used as a raw material in the IPN unit.  Metaxylene and ammonia are reacted together with catalyst to make IPN.  Ammonia enters the plant by rail car or tank truck, and is stored in a 12,000 gallon storage tank.

The plant has a chlorine distribution process which provides liquid chlorine to the CTL unit.  Chlorine comes into the plant in rail cars and is then transferred to the CTL unit via pipeline.  The liquid chlorine is vaporized in the CTL unit and is then fed into the process.

Section 6 ? Accident History

Over the past 5 years, the facility has experienced two accidental releases that met the RMP reporting criteria.  One incident occurred on May 19, 2000 and involved the release of 20 pounds of chlorine from the CTL process.  The incident resulted in one on-site injury and no off-site impacts.  The other incident occurred on February 12, 2003 and involved the release of 371 pounds of chlorine from the West Cooling Tower.  This incident resulted in an on-site shelter-in-place and the evacuation of 20 people from a nearby off-site facility.

Section 7 ? Prevention Program Level 3

GB Biosciences has two (2) regulated chemicals above the threshold quantity-ammonia and chlorine.  GB Biosciences has identified three covered processes ? IPN process, CTL process, and chlorine distribution.  The processes co

rrespond to the plant layout and the way the process hazard analyses (PHA) were performed.  Each process unit conducted a global process hazard analysis using the HAZOP methodology.  Projects and changes are handled with management of change (MOC) procedures.  As required, these changes undergo an appropriate PHA (Whatif/Checklist, Checklist, FMEA, Fault tree, etc.).  The PHAs presented in the RMP Plan are the comprehensive unit HAZOPs.  On a five year interval, the unit HAZOPs are re-validated and updated according to PHA findings.

The equipment for each area has been screened to determine if it can result in a catastrophic release to the environment.  This equipment has been classified as PSM covered.  This equipment is inspected on a frequency determined internally, based on past performance.  Any problems found during the inspections are repaired in a timely manner.

There are both operating and maintenance procedures for each unit.  These procedures are reviewed and certified on an annual basis.  GB Biosciences has developed computer based training (CBT) for each procedure.  Individuals affected by a procedure must perform a CBT for that procedure and pass a subsequent written test once per year.  Training records are kept of this activity.

All incidents are investigated to determine cause and to prevent recurrence.

Changes to Improve Safety:

During 1997 the Ammonia Storage Tank capacity was significantly reduced.  The storage capacity went from 60,000 gallons to 12,000 gallons.

Formation of release reduction teams in the IPN and CTL areas.

Recent Venture II project reduced the amount of chlorine in the CTL unit.

The two chlorine vaporizers previously in the chlorine distribution area were shutdown and replaced with one significantly smaller chlorine vaporizer installed in the CTL unit.

Section 8 ? Prevention Program Level 2

No program level 2 processes.

Section 9 ? Emergency Response

The Greens Bayou site has a 24 hour emergency response system in p

lace.  The site operates under an Incident Command System (ICS) for all emergencies.  GB Biosciences has personnel on site trained to respond to fires, hazardous material releases, medical needs, and rescue situations 24 hours a day, seven days a week.  Emergency team members are issued alpha numeric pagers so that they can be notified for assistance as needed.  The shift facilitator is the Incident Commander.  Quarterly training is received by all emergency responders.

GB Biosciences is a member of the Channel Industries Mutual Aid organization (CIMA).  CIMA is one of the largest mutual aid organizations offering emergency response assistance to member companies.  GB Biosciences participates in annual functional emergency response drills and training days with CIMA.

Additionally, GB Biosciences has representation on the Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC) and the local Community Awareness and Emergency Response (CAER) group.  GB Biosciences personnel also participate in functional drills with the LEPC and the CAER group.  Both of these groups include the local fire department, sheriff?s department, ambulance services, local hospital, neighboring industries and business owners.

GB Biosciences utilizes a computer driven voice message alarm system to communicate to the plant population, the type and location of an emergency.  Critical plant personnel are also equipped with portable radios to aid in communications during an emergency.  Radios are also in place for instant communications with neighboring industries and other CIMA members.  Mobile radios have access to common state wide mutual air frequencies to contact the fire department and ambulance service, including the local air ambulance (Life Flight).  The LEPC is currently installing an area telephone alerting system, known as First Call, to contact area residents in the event of an incident that might have impact on the community.

GB Biosciences has it own internal fire water system (with backup supp

ly).  Most operating areas have fixed fire water systems installed and perimeter fixed fire monitors.  Some areas have fixed gas detection systems in place to identify a possible leak and initiate an alarm in the appropriate control room for action.  Video monitors have been installed in some areas allowing for continuous monitoring, primarily of railcar unloading areas.

Local, state, and federal environmental agencies are contacted if the notification of an environmental release is necessary.
